body:
This looks as if it would block until the SSL stack is actually able to send the close notify. 

If the outgoing socket is "full", EGAIN is returned. SSL would convert that into an SSL_WANT_WRITE. This would then hang forever in a busy loop (we are non-blocking so this would 100% CPU) until the server reads from its end of the socket.

TLS close notify handling and merits have been debated for years. We treat *sending* it as a "best effort" before closing the socket. And that is what the code does. I think it disproportional to block before closing of the socket - at the mercy of the other end or a middle box. This would halt any other ongoing transfer in curl.

I believe this is not worth it. But I am no expert on FTP and its attack vectors.

Hello Stefan,
Thank you for your swift answer. I am no OpenSSL expert. Just placed a tracepoint after the call of SSL_shutdown() and discovered that it failed frequently in my particular setup (wobbly data link using WiFi or cellular phone network). Then I monitored the number of retries (still with a tracepoint) and found that a *single* retry always fixed the issue, and dispatched the TLS alert close_notify. It just happens to work for me. Limiting the number of iterations would probably make sense, though.About the close_notify alert mandated by TLSv1.3, I discovered that there is much controversy. But I talk to a FileZilla server using GnuTLS, which is adamant that it receive the close_notify before detecting socket closure.
If my humble suggestion does not make its way into the codebase, this not a big deal for me, I'll just check openssl.c in future versions of curl, and apply my patch for my own needs. I always build curl from sources, so this is not an issue.
With best regards,Alain


   Le lundi 26 juin 2023 à 09:31:29 UTC+2, Stefan Eissing ***@***.***> a écrit :  
 
 


This looks as if it would block until the SSL stack is actually able to send the close notify.

If the outgoing socket is "full", EGAIN is returned. SSL would convert that into an SSL_WANT_WRITE. This would then hang forever in a busy loop (we are non-blocking so this would 100% CPU) until the server reads from its end of the socket.

TLS close notify handling and merits have been debated for years. We treat sending it as a "best effort" before closing the socket. And that is what the code does. I think it disproportional to block before closing of the socket - at the mercy of the other end or a middle box. This would halt any other ongoing transfer in curl.

I believe this is not worth it. But I am no expert on FTP and its attack vectors.

—

You are receiving this because you authored the thread.Message ID: ***@***.***>
  

|  | Virus-free.www.avast.com |

We actually do see this issue a lot, especially with FileZilla servers, but also with VSFTP (there, the server response is `426 Failure reading network stream`). Interestingly, this does not happen just at random and at instable wireless connections, but seems to depend solely on the file size and connection speed to the server - and repeated attempts at uploading a file of that particular size all fail in the same way.

In particular, I've seen one server where it is impossible to upload a file of size 9977696 bytes. The client always runs on windows 10 and I have no way to run a debug version of curl, just using the "official" windows binaries directly from the curl project. However I was able to debug this on the level of Winsock's `send` function - and in cases where the upload fails that way, it's always that the last `send` on the data connection fails with `WSAEWOULDBLOCK`. This of course also happens a lot already  during the actual upload of the file, but those `send`s are properly repeated after waiting for it to unblock, but the last one is not. It seems that this particular server is rather slow, and with just the right file size, the last `send` of the real file data just fills the socket's send buffer enough that the following `send` for the close notify is almost guaranteed to fail... 

So it would really be nice if a more robust attempt at sending the close_notify could be made.

> In particular, I've seen one server where it is impossible to upload a file of size 9977696 bytes. The client always runs on windows 10 and I have no way to run a debug version of curl, just using the "official" windows binaries directly from the curl project. However I was able to debug this on the level of Winsock's `send` function - and in cases where the upload fails that way, it's always that the last `send` on the data connection fails with `WSAEWOULDBLOCK`.

Try using [SSLKEYLOGFILE](https://everything.curl.dev/usingcurl/tls/sslkeylogfile) to confirm what is actually sent at the end

> Try using [SSLKEYLOGFILE](https://everything.curl.dev/usingcurl/tls/sslkeylogfile) to confirm what is actually sent at the end

After the file is transferred completely, the close_notify alert is sent, and we also get one back from the server.

```
6799  12.595762   172.XX.XX.XX  77.YY.YYY.YY  TCP       54      54333 ? 56170 [ACK] Seq=9991781 Ack=243 Win=262400 Len=0
```
There is no close_notify alert on the wire, and the connection is closed. I also verified that the whole file data is present up to the last byte. 

I saw that under this particular configuration, the actual payload data is processed into chunks of up to 16384 bytes each, and for each of those, an indivudal `send` is done, containing on TLS application data packet. As a result, the "critical" case is when `file_size % 16384` get's close to the maximum of 16383. 
Original file size was 9977696 (which has a remainder of 16224), but I was able to reliably reproduce the missing close_notify also with sizes of 1785696 and 1458016.  

*gvanem, Edited* removed the TABs and narrowed the columns a bit to make it readable. The typos remains.

Could you check if #11858 helps with the shutdown problems?

UPDATE: sorry, #11858 isn't yet in the state it should be. I'll update when done.
UPDATE: now it's in a state to be tested.

I don't have the infrastructure to build custom versions of curl for windows, so I can't really test this PR.

However, I don't see how the lastest changes in #11858 would help here. In the scenario described above, the code would end ìn `CURL_TRC_CF(data, cf, "SSL shutdown, blocked send, leaving");` and give up, as it did before. I understand that you do not want to add longer block times, but maybe a single attempt at re-sending the close-notify only in the `SSL_ERROR_WANT_WRITE` case, after waiting only a few milliseconds, could mitigate this issue well enough in practice.
Is this still failing the same way using current git master?

As I said, I don't have the infrastructure to build custom versions of curl for windows, so I can't really test any git versions. However, looking at the master source: https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/5691a6cf363242da38bd7e469b13a2e741a295c6/lib/vtls/openssl.c#L1915-L1917  

A blocked close_notify send attempt is still just ignored and not repeated. Are there any other recent code changes which should prevent this from happening?

Unfortunatelty, I also don't have access to this server which "reliably" had shown this behavior any more.
What I can say is that we still saw this issue with 8.5.0 in the wild, with different servers. However, due to the nature of this issue being so timing-critical, it's hard to reproduce on purpose.
